title: 113_s1744
content:
The Act is titled the "Security Clearance Accountability, Reform, and Enhancement Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Security Clearance Accountability, Reform, and Enhancement Act" defines key terms such as "agency," "appropriate agency," and "appropriate congressional committees." The "Security Clearance Accountability, Reform, and Enhancement Act" defines terms like "background investigation" and "covered contract" related to security clearances and federal employment. The "Security Clearance Accountability, Reform, and Enhancement Act" defines terms like "covered contract" as a contract for background investigations between agencies, prime contractors, and subcontractors, and "covered individual" as someone working for or seeking to work for an agency. It also defines "covered misconduct" as misconduct that affects the integrity of background investigations conducted by or for an agency. The term "prime contractor" refers to an individual who contracts with an agency, while a "subcontractor" is an individual contracted by a prime contractor or another subcontractor to work on behalf of an agency. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY OF INDIVIDUALS INVOLVED IN MISCONDUCT AFFECTING THE INTEGRITY OF AGENCY BACKGROUND INVESTIGATIONS. (a) Misconduct by Federal Employees:
- If an agency finds that an employee has engaged in misconduct, they will be deemed unfit for Federal employment.
- The agency must follow relevant procedures for investigating employee misconduct.
- Individuals deemed unfit for Federal employment cannot work in positions requiring background investigations.

(b) Misconduct by Employees Under Contract. (b) Misconduct by Employees Under Contract:
- Individuals found to have engaged in covered misconduct under a covered contract are ineligible to perform background investigations.
- A provision in a covered contract mandates disclosure of any allegations of covered misconduct by employees within 24 hours of discovery.
- Investigations into covered misconduct are required under a covered contract. (A) Contractor investigation.--A covered contract requires prime contractors or subcontractors to refer allegations of covered misconduct to the agency for investigation within 5 business days of disclosure. 
(B) Agency investigation.--An appropriate agency can conduct its own investigation into allegations of covered misconduct. 
Prohibition on reemployment for individuals found ineligible to work under a covered contract based on investigation results. The individual found ineligible to work under a covered contract will be prohibited from performing background investigations. Existing contracts must be modified to include required provisions within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The President must report annually on the number of individuals unfit for Federal employment or ineligible to work under a covered contract. The individual found ineligible to work under a covered contract will be prohibited from performing background investigations. The President must report annually on the number of individuals unfit for Federal employment or ineligible to work under a covered contract, including details of the covered misconduct. SEC. 4. REVIEW AND UPDATE OF POSITION DESIGNATION GUIDANCE. The President must review and update guidance on position sensitivity designation and background investigations within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Every 5 years, position designations must be reviewed and revised by the President through relevant agencies. Reports to Congress must be submitted within 30 days of completion. The President must submit a report to Congress within 30 days after completing a review on any issues identified and the number of position designations revised. This section does not change the authority of agencies to designate sensitive positions or those requiring access to classified information. The Senate passed S. 1744 on December 15, 2014, an act to enhance accountability for misconduct in background investigations and update position designation guidelines.
